###

Lab 2: Matplotlib

**Goals:** In this notebook we are going to experiment with practical aspects of data science, in particular the application of the *Matplotlib* library. We will use a structured dataset (*Iris Dataset*). This notebook will follow contents in Chapter 4 of the [*Python Data Science Handbook*](https://jakevdp.github.io/PythonDataScienceHandbook/). Please check the book to gain some insight on how to solve the exercises and participate with questions/comments in your lab session. Using the Pandas library we will: - Read a file and load it to a DataFrame Using the Matplotlib library we will: - Plot data (Line plot, Scatter plot, Histogram, Box plot)

Matplotlib

Matplotlib is the package for visualization in Python. We will now use the previous dataset and produce some visualizations. Just as we use the pd shorthand for Pandas, we will use mpl and plt as standard shorthands for Matplotlib imports. A potentially confusing feature of Matplotlib is its dual interfaces: a MATLAB-style state-based interface, and a more powerful object-oriented interface. In our Labs we will mainly use the object-oriented interface as it provides greater flexibility. In practice, we will always call methods over an object Axes. We will first see some plot types and then plot quantities of interest related with the Happiness Report 2022 dataset.

import matplotlib
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

import numpy as np # Used only to create some examples based on known functions like sin and cos

# First create a grid of plots
# ax will be an array of two Axes objects
fig, ax = plt.subplots(2)

x = np.arange(0,10,0.1)

# Call plot() method on the appropriate object
ax[0].plot(x, np.sin(x))
ax[1].plot(x, np.cos(x));

fig, ax = plt.subplots()

x = np.linspace(0, 10, 30)
y = np.sin(x)

ax.plot(x, y, 'o', color='black');

fig, ax = plt.subplots()

x = np.linspace(0, 10, 50)
dy = 0.8
y = np.sin(x) + dy

ax.boxplot([x,y], labels=["x","y"])

plt.show()

ax = plt.subplot()

data = np.random.randn(1000)

ax.hist(data)

plt.show()
The code below loads a CSV file into a pandas dataframe. Today we use the Iris datase, you can find more information about this dataset here: https://archive.ics.uci.edu/dataset/53/iris

import pandas as pd
#If No such file or directory error, make sure that the iris.csv file is in the same folder as this notebook 
# Alternativelly use the full path for iris.csv e.g., C:\Users\<CurrentUserName>\iris.csv
iris_data_frame = pd.read_csv('iris.csv') 

iris_data_frame
The code below reports the distribution of sepal length using an histogram.

# using matplotlib explicitly
x = iris_data_frame['sepallength']
fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.hist(x)

ax.set_xlabel("Sepal Length")
plt.show()
The code below creates a scatter plot to visualize the distribution in terms of sepal length and sepal width.

x = iris_data_frame['sepallength']
y = iris_data_frame['sepalwidth']

fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.scatter(x, y,c='black')

ax.set_xlabel("Length")
ax.set_ylabel("Width")
ax.set_title("Sepal Lenght vs Width")

plt.show()
